head.title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Opposition Protests Continue

hedline.hl1: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Opposition Protests Continue

block.p: About 8,000 demonstrators gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakiev's office in Bishkek, the capital, for an eighth day of protests against him, and added a call for new parliamentary elections to their list of demands for sweeping government reforms. They have already demanded new presidential elections. Mr. Bakiev has initiated a number of compromises with the opposition in recent weeks, including appointing a critic as prime minister. Protest leaders are calling for larger demonstrations over the weekend.

About 8,000 demonstrators gathered near President Kurmanbek Bakiev's office in Bishkek, the capital, for an eighth day of protests against him, and added a call for new parliamentary elections to their list of demands for sweeping government reforms. They have already demanded new presidential elections. Mr. Bakiev has initiated a number of compromises with the opposition in recent weeks, including appointing a critic as prime minister. Protest leaders are calling for larger demonstrations over the weekend.

Correction: April 20, 2007, Friday The headline on a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about opposition protests referred incorrectly in some copies to the country where the protests took place. They were in Kyrgyzstan, not Kazakhstan.
